Award.AwardTitle: Preparing Students for Writing in Civil Engineering Practice: Research-based Materials Development and Assessment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is addressing a persistent problem in engineering education: the mismatch between the writing skills of program graduates and the demands of writing in the workplace. This project is identifying problems in undergraduate student writing by analyzing student writing and high quality practitioner writing. A team of linguists and engineers is then addressing the problems by developing teaching materials that integrate instruction about effective organization, grammar, and vocabulary into civil engineering classes. After the use of the new materials, student writing improvement is being assessed from multiple perspectives that cover language features, organization, and overall effectiveness. The project has many innovative features that contribute to its intellectual merit: the integration of engineering practitioners' perspectives into classroom teaching materials, the synthesis of writing skills and engineering content, the use of empirical analysis to identify student writing weaknesses, and the application of multiple methods to assess the instructional materials' effectiveness. The project's broader impacts include the participation of universities with a high percentage of students from groups that are underrepresented in civil engineering; stronger writing skills can facilitate their participation in this field. Furthermore, effective communication has been found to be the single largest variable in infrastructure project success; poor communication in documents can lead to a waste of time and taxpayer dollars and even to injuries and death. Thus, the benefits of teaching civil engineers to write more effectively extend far beyond the profession of civil engineering itself.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addressed a persistent problem in civil engineering education: the mismatch between the writing skills of program graduates and the demands of writing in the workplace. Overall, the project found that students' writing improved significantly when the students received explicit instruction that tied writing skills to civil engineering content and practice. The writing was more effective for meeting concerns expressed by engineers in the workplace. Specifically, the students' word choices, grammar, and organization better met concerns that practitioners had for accuracy, precision, liability, credibility and client expectations. The project relied on collaboration among engineering practitioners, engineering faculty, and applied linguists (who study how people adapt their language for different contexts and purposes).

The project had four major components. First, we identified the most serious student writing weaknesses by analyzing differences between student writing and effective workplace writing. We compiled a text corpus of practitioner documents from 40 civil engineering workplaces and student papers from four different universities, including a Historically Black University, a Hispanic-serving Institution, and a university with a high percentage of immigrant and nontraditional students. We used techniques from applied linguistics to analyze the differences between the student and practitioner writing quantitatively and qualitatively. We also interviewed practitioners to identify the problems that would be most serious in the workplace.  The problems included specific language features - such as inappropriately absolute words and extremely complicated sentence structures - and global issues, such as missing information or disjointed organization. We used interviews with students to identify reasons behind the writing problems. For example, students often held misconceptions about characteristics of effective writing in engineering practice.  

Second, we developed teaching materials to address the greatest student writing weaknesses. We made five "Genre Units," which explained typical document types and their content, organization and formatting (e.g., geotechnical site visit investigation reports, field observations memos). We developed eight "Language Units," which explained how to choose between different grammatical choices (for example, when to use a  simple sentence rather than a complex sentence, or how to choose between active and passive voice). We also made eight "Grammar and Mechanics Lessons," which addressed the most common errors students made in standard written English. All the materials included examples of effective practitioner writing, tips for revising ineffective writing, and practice activities.

The third component was to assess the effectiveness of the new materials after they were used in civil engineering courses. We collected papers that students from the four universities wrote after using the materials and compared them to previous papers. We analyzed seven major characteristics that covered linguistic features (such as sentence structure), genre features (such as organization), and errors in standard written English (such as inaccurate punctuation). An engineering practitioner also evaluated the overall effectiveness of papers. The results were positive for all characteristics and at all levels of the undergraduate curriculum. In interviews and surveys, students were positive about the materials, especially appreciating examples of real practitioner writing and concrete techniques for revising ineffective writing.  Interview comments also showed that students were gaining a more accurate understanding of effective writing for engineering practice. For example, students made many comments about working to be concise and to choose words for accuracy rather than trying to look smart by using complicated sentences and long words. 

The final component concerned sharing the teaching materials and the results of our analyses in a variety of publications, workshops, and conferences. We developed a project website - the Civil Engineering Writing Project - where all the materials are publicly available. During the period of the project, the materials were used at 15 universities and by individuals already in industry practice. We shared what we learned with five communities: engineering faculty, engineering practitioners, applied linguists, writing specialists, and English as a Second Language teachers. All of these groups are important for the continued training of civil engineers.

Since communication is a major variable affecting infrastructure project success - including whether projects are on time, on budget, and safe - all taxpayers and residents benefit when civil engineers can write more effectively. Furthermore, the materials had significant positive effects on writing by groups that are underrepresented in engineering, including African Americans and Hispanics. Stronger writing skills can facilitate their greater participation in the field. Finally, the project illustrated the benefits of collaboration among language specialists, academic engineering faculty, and engineers in industry. No single group could have researched the student problems, developed materials, and assessed their effectiveness as comprehensively as the collaborative team did. Although this project focused on civil engineering, the design could be applied to other fields.
